expectations.text: The PR title follows the conventional commit format: type(scope): Summary
expectations.evidence: PR title in response.md is: `feat(auth): add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication`. This matches the pattern type(scope): summary exactly — 'feat' is the type, 'auth' is the scope, and the remainder is the summary.

expectations.text: The PR title uses one of the valid types: feat, fix, perf, test, docs, refactor, build, ci, chore, or revert
expectations.evidence: The PR title begins with 'feat', which is explicitly listed as a valid type. Confirmed in response.md line 5: `feat(auth): add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication`.

expectations.text: The PR title summary starts with a capital letter
expectations.evidence: The summary portion of the PR title (after 'feat(auth): ') is 'add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication'. It begins with a lowercase 'a', not a capital letter. Found in response.md line 5 and also in the gh pr create command at line 83.

expectations.text: The PR title summary does not end with a period
expectations.evidence: The PR title ends with 'authentication' — no trailing period. Confirmed in response.md line 5: `feat(auth): add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication`.

expectations.text: The response includes a 'gh pr create' command
expectations.evidence: response.md contains a full gh pr create command starting at line 82: `gh pr create \` with --title, --body, --base, and --head flags fully specified.

expectations.text: The PR body contains a Summary section
expectations.evidence: The PR body in response.md (lines 13-17 and mirrored in the gh pr create heredoc at lines 85-90) contains a `## Summary` section with three bullet points describing what the PR does.

expectations.text: The PR body contains a Related Issues section
expectations.evidence: The PR body in response.md (line 49-51 and mirrored in the gh pr create heredoc at lines 120-123) contains a `## Related Issues` section with the placeholder text 'Closes #<issue-number>'.

expectations.text: The PR body contains a Checklist section
expectations.evidence: The PR body does not contain a section named 'Checklist'. The closest section is '## Test Plan' (lines 28-34 in the body) which uses checkbox syntax (`- [x]`), but it is not labeled 'Checklist'. No section with that name appears anywhere in response.md.

expectations.text: The response includes or mentions a git push command
expectations.evidence: response.md line 79 contains: `git push -u origin feat/jwt-oauth2-auth` as step 6 in the commands sequence, preceded by the comment '# 6. Push the feature branch to remote'.

claims.claim: PR title uses `feat` prefix (conventional commits standard)
claims.evidence: Confirmed in response.md: title is `feat(auth): add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication`.

claims.claim: PR title is concise and under 72 characters
claims.evidence: Title 'feat(auth): add OAuth2 login support with JWT authentication' is 60 characters, well under the 72-character limit stated in transcript Step 2.

claims.claim: The PR body includes a Changes section listing modified and new files
claims.evidence: response.md contains a '## Changes' section with 'Modified Files' (login.ts, middleware.ts) and 'New Files' (tests/auth.test.ts) subsections.

claims.claim: Security Considerations section is present in the PR body
claims.evidence: response.md lines 36-40 contain a '## Security Considerations' section covering JWT signing, expiration, and OAuth2 compliance.

claims.claim: The PR was actually created (gh pr create was executed)
claims.evidence: The transcript describes composing and saving the gh pr create command, but there is no evidence the command was actually run. The output directory was initially 'empty' (transcript Step 1) and the executor only saved files — no gh CLI output or PR URL is recorded.

suggestions.assertion: The PR body contains a Checklist section
suggestions.reason: The assertion is ambiguous: it could mean a section literally named 'Checklist', or any section containing checkbox-style items. The output has '## Test Plan' with checkboxes, which satisfies the spirit but not the letter. Clarifying whether the section must be named 'Checklist' vs. merely contain checklist-style items would make this assertion more discriminating and easier to evaluate consistently.

No assertion checks whether the PR was actually created (i.e., gh pr create was executed and returned a URL). The output only contains a command to be run, not evidence of actual execution. An assertion like 'The response includes a PR URL' or 'gh pr create was executed successfully' would catch the difference between generating instructions and actually creating the PR.

suggestions.assertion: The PR body contains a Related Issues section
suggestions.reason: The Related Issues section contains only a placeholder ('Closes #<issue-number>') rather than a real issue reference. The assertion passes because the section exists, but the content is empty/template. A stricter assertion would verify the section references an actual issue number.

eval_feedback.overall: The two failures (lowercase summary start, no 'Checklist' section) are genuine and meaningful. The eval set is reasonably solid but misses the important question of whether the PR was actually created versus merely described. The Related Issues section placeholder is a quality gap no assertion catches.
